z:row.TitlePrimary: Elevated-pressure mixed-coolants Joule-Thomson cryocooling
z:row.Publisher: Elsevier Ltd, Oxford, OX5 1GB, United Kingdom
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: This paper explores the potential of mixed coolants at elevated pressures for Joule-Thomson cryocooling. A numerical model of a Joule-Thomson cryocooler is developed that is capable of simulating operation with mixtures of up to 9 components consisting of hydrocarbons, non-flammable halogenated refrigerants, and inert gases. The numerical model is integrated with a genetic optimization algorithm, which has a high capability for convergence in an environment of discontinuities, constraints and local optima. The genetic optimization algorithm is used to select the optimal mixture compositions that separately maximizes following two objective functions at each elevated pressure for 80, 90 and 95 K cryocooling: the molar specific cooling capacity (the highest attainable is 3200 J/mol) and the produced cooling capacity per thermal conductance which is a measure of the compactness of the recuperator. The optimized cooling capacity for a non-flammable halogenated refrigerant mixture is smaller than for a hydrocarbon mixture; however, the cooling capacity of the two types of mixtures approach one another as pressure becomes higher. The coefficient of performance, the required heat transfer area and the effect of the number of components in the mixture is investigated as a function of the pressure. It is shown that mixtures with more components provide a higher cooling capacity but require larger recuperative heat exchangers. Optimized mixtures for 90 K cryocooling have similar cooling capacity as those for 80 K. Optimized compactness for 80 K is about 50% higher than can be achieved by pure nitrogen. For 90 K, no mixture provides a more compact recuperator than can be achieved using pure argon. The results are discussed in the context of potential applications for closed and open cycle cryocoolers.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Joule-Thomson coolers (E); Gas mixture (B); Cycle optimization (E); Cryocooling

z:row.TitlePrimary: Double-sided IPEM cooling using miniature heat pipes
z:row.Keyword: Power electronics|Heat pipes|Cooling|Thermal gradients|Specific heat|Electric conductivity|Electric conductance|Heat flux|Soldered joints|Finite element method|Mathematical models
z:row.PeriodicalFull: IEEE Transactions on Components and Packaging Technologies
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc., Piscataway, NJ 08855-1331, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Integrated power electronic module (IPEM) planar interconnect technologies offer opportunities for improved thermal management by allowing thermal access to the upper side of the power devices. In this paper, the feasibility of using miniature heat pipes to achieve effective double-sided cooling is investigated by analyzing the complete thermal circuit associated with the power device. A nominal case was modeled using the ANSYS(tm) finite element software in a single-sided and double-sided configuration. The numerical model predicted that the double-sided configuration would result in a 13 °C reduction in the maximum temperature compared to the single-sided case, for the same 100 W/cm2 power dissipation in the semiconductor die. This corresponds to a 15 % decrease in the maximum temperature rise relative to ambient or a similar increase in allowable power dissipation. Twenty-eight percent of the heat was removed from the upper side of the IPEM in the double-sided case. An additional benefit associated with double-sided cooling was a significant reduction in the spatial temperature gradients along the surface of the IPEM which would translate to lower thermally induced stress and higher reliability. The sensitivity of the numerical predictions to important parameters; including the dielectric conductivity, contact conductance, and heat sink characteristics are numerically investigated. An experimental fixture was fabricated and used to measure a miniature rectangular heat pipe's performance characteristics and the solder joint resistance at its evaporator and condenser interfaces in order to validate the numerical model inputs and demonstrate the required heat pipe capacity. The tested heat pipe was limited to approximately 80 W/cm2 heat flux in a vertical, evaporator-over-condenser orientation. This limit was not observed in a vertical, gravity-assisted orientation for applied heat flux up to 125 W/cm2. Equivalent heat pipe resistances of approximately 0.12 and 0.08 K/W were measured in these orientations, respectively. The contact resistance of the indium solder joint was measured and found to be approximately 0.1 cm2. K/ W. © 2005 IEEE.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Integrated power electronic module (IPEM); Thermal management; Double-sided cooling; Spatial temperature gradients

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effectiveness-NTU relationship for a counterflow heat exchanger subjected to an external heat transfer
z:row.Keyword: Heat exchangers|Heat transfer|Heat flux|Temperature|Thermal load|Cryogenic equipment|Process engineering|Mathematical models|Integral equations
z:row.Publisher: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, New York, NY 10016-5990, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: This paper presents the analytical solution for the effectiveness of a counterflow heat exchanger subjected to a uniformly distributed, external heat flux. The solution is verified against conventional ε-NTU relations in the limit of zero external heat flux. This situation is of interest in applications such as cryogenic and process engineering, and the analytical solution provides a convenient method for treating difterential elements of a heat exchanger in a numerical model. Copyright © 2005 by ASME.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Counterflow heat exchanger; External heat transfer; Temperature difference

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental investigation and modeling of inertance tubes
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Fluids Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
z:row.Publisher: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, New York, NY 10016-5990, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Cryogenic Engineering Laboratory, Engineering Research Building, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Growing interest in larger scale pulse tubes has focused attention on optimizing their thermodynamic efficiency. For Stirling-type pulse tubes, the performance is governed by the phase difference between the pressure and mass flow, a characteristic that can be conveniently adjusted through the use of inertance tubes. In this paper we present a model in which the inertance tube is divided into a large number of increments; each increment is represented by a resistance, compliance, and inertance. This model can include local variations along the inertance tube and is capable of predicting pressure, mass flow rate, and the phase between these quantities at any location in the inertance tube as well as in the attached reservoir. The model is verified through careful comparison with those quantities that can be easily and reliably measured; these include the pressure variations along the length of the inertance tube and the mass flow rate into the reservoir. These experimental quantities are shown to be in good agreement with the model's predictions over a wide range of operating conditions. Design charts are subsequently generated using the model and are presented for various operating conditions in order to facilitate the design of inertance tubes for pulse tube refrigerators. These design charts enable the pulse tube designer to select an inertance tube geometry that achieves a desired phase shift for a given level of acoustic power. Copyright © 2005 by ASME.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: inertance tube; mass flow rate; Pressure variations; Thermodynamic efficiency

z:row.TitlePrimary: Heat transfer coefficient measurements for mixed gas working fluids at cryogenic temperatures
z:row.Publisher: Elsevier Ltd, Oxford, OX5 1GB, United Kingdom
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: The use of mixed gas working fluids has become common in Joule-Thomson type cryocoolers for a variety of applications. However, there is very little data or theory currently available regarding the heat transfer coefficient associated with these multi-component, multi-phase mixtures at cryogenic temperatures. This paper describes an experimental test facility and procedure that has been used to make careful measurements of the horizontal, flow boiling heat transfer coefficient for several hydrocarbon mixtures that are nominally optimal for small, Joule-Thomson cryocoolers in the 80 K to 120 K operating range. Data are presented over a range of temperatures from 100 K to room temperature and for several pressures and mass flow rates. The results indicate that quality and mass flux are the most important parameters governing the heat transfer coefficient among those that were varied. The experiment is verified by carrying out tests using single-phase, pure nitrogen gas and comparing the results with the Dittus-Boelter equation. The experimental uncertainty of the measurements is estimated from 1st principles; additionally, the repeatability of the experimental measurements was investigated by replicating tests at a nominal set of operating conditions and composition on separate days. The measurements presented here are intended to aid in the design of small, mixed-gas Joule-Thomson cryocoolers. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Mixed-gas working fluids; Joule-Thomson cryocoolers; Multi-phase mixtures; Hydrocarbon mixtures

z:row.TitlePrimary: Eddy current heating in micro-SMES bus-bars
z:row.Keyword: Superconductivity|Magnetic field effects|Energy storage|Busbars|Induction heating|Superconducting films|Superconducting magnets|Cooling|Thermal effects|Mathematical models
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc., Piscataway, NJ 08855-1331, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Applied Superconductivity Center, Departments of Mechanical Engineering and Engineering Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Results from numerical models and theoretical analyses are presented that describe the development of eddy current heating in copper bus bars, both with and without superconducting elements, in response to the rapid decay of current in a nearby superconducting magnet such as in micro-SMES systems. The analysis differs from those available in the open literature in that the change of magnetic field is neither instantaneous, nor sinusoidal. We especially investigate eddy current heating in the regime where the field decay time is on the order of the current diffusion time constant. It is found that the self-inductance of the copper bus bar contributes significantly to the time dependent heat generation. Analytical results are compared to experimental data in the form of subsequent temperature excursions of a liquid helium cooled copper bus, in response to field ramp rates on the order of 1.5 tesla/second. © 2005 IEEE.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Micro-SMES; Transient film boiling; Superconducting elements; Field decay times

z:row.TitlePrimary: Actively cooled current leads for superconducting electronics using mixed-gas joule-thomson refrigeration
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2004 ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, IMECE, Nov 13-19 2004
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
z:row.Keyword: Superconducting magnets|Refrigeration|Thermal conductivity|Thermal load|Cryogenics|Entropy|Heat exchangers|Energy transfer
z:row.Publisher: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, New York, NY 10016-5990, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Electrical leads used for the supply of current to superconducting magnets and electronics must span the temperature range from room temperature to cryogenic temperatures. Because the conventional materials used for such purposes (e.g., copper and aluminum) have both a finite electrical resistance and a significant thermal conductivity, operation of the leads results in both thermal generation and conductance. The resulting thermal loads must be removed from the cryogenic environment. This paper describes a method for integrating cryogenic refrigeration technology with current leads in an efficient and practical manner. The key to this concept is the use of a mixed-gas cooling cycle that absorbs the distributed refrigeration load continuously over the temperature range that it is generated, as opposed to allowing it to pass down to the cold end of the lead where the same energy flow constitutes a much higher entropy load on the cryocooler. Additional benefits of this technology include a more isothermal electronic package, as well as improvements in reliability, and reduction in size and mass. Mixed-gas working fluids can be used within Joule-Thomson devices to achieve a greater refrigeration effect for the same pressure span than is possible with a pure substance. This paper describes a computational tool that allows the composition of gas mixtures to be optimized for the case where the refrigeration load is not completely concentrated at the cold end, as is typically the case, but rather the refrigeration load is distributed over the entire temperature range. A genetic optimization algorithm was found to be the most robust and reliable technique for identifying optimum gas mixture composition. The thermodynamic advantage associated with accepting the refrigeration load at the temperature of its origin, rather than at the cold end, is quantified. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Mixed-gas Joule-Thomson (MGJT); Superconducting electronics; Genetic optimization algorithm; Refrigeration load

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of heat transfer coefficients for non-azeotropic hydrocarbon mixtures at cryogenic temperatures
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2004 ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, IMECE, Nov 13-19 2004
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
z:row.Publisher: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, New York, NY 10016-5990, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: The use of non-azeotropic hydrocarbon mixtures in throttle-cycle refrigeration systems has resulted in large increases in the performance of Joule-Thomson type cryocoolers. However, there is very little data or theory currently available in the literature regarding the thermal-fluid behavior of multi-component, multi-phase mixtures at cryogenic temperatures. The design of these systems is therefore semi-empirical, relying heavily on experimental iteration. In this paper, an experimental apparatus is described that is capable of making precise and controlled measurements of the heat transfer coefficient over a range of cryogenic temperatures, compositions, geometries, and flow rates that are relevant to small-scale, throttle-cycle refrigeration systems. The experimental apparatus is used to carry out a study of the horizontal flow boiling heat transfer coefficient for a non-azeotropic hydrocarbon mixture in a circular cross-section with a constant wall temperature. The measurements are carried out over a range of cryogenic temperatures and the data is presented in the form of heat transfer coefficient as a function of temperature and thermodynamic quality. The experimental uncertainty of the measurements is theoretically estimated to be 10%. Measurements of the single-phase heat transfer coefficient for pure nitrogen fall within 10% of the Dittus-Boelter correlation. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Boelter correlation; Flow rates; Working fluid; Cryosurgical probes

z:row.TitlePrimary: Design and test of 300W, 65K pulse tube
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2004 ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, IMECE, Nov 13-19 2004
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
z:row.Keyword: Tubes (components)|Specific heat|Heat transfer|Regenerators|Compressors|Electric charge|Thermal conductivity|Heat exchangers|Viscosity|Nusselt number|Reynolds number|Entropy|Optimization|Computational fluid dynamics
z:row.Publisher: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, New York, NY 10016-5990, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin- Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: This paper describes the design and preliminary experimental results for a large capacity (300W at 65 K) single-stage, Stirling-type pulse-tube. The regenerator, the critical component in the pulse-tube, was optimized via a parametric study accomplished using the REGENv3.2 program. The pulse tube system was subsequently designed using a 1st order model that calculates the pressure-flow characteristics of the system coupled with 2 nd order models of the various internal loss mechanisms. An experimental pulse-tube system was fabricated based on this design; the pulse-tube apparatus allows simultaneous, high frequency measurement of instantaneous compressor piston position as well the instantaneous pressures at various locations in the system. In addition, the average temperatures along the regenerator, within the cold heat exchanger gas volume, on the cold heat exchanger surface, and along the pulse-tube are measured. This comprehensive set of measurements will allow a thorough evaluation and verification of the design model over a wide range of operating conditions including compressor stroke, frequency, charge pressure, and load temperature. This paper presents some preliminary experimental progress and compares the measured pressure-flow behavior with the design model predictions. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Charge pressure; Load temperature; Cold heat exchanger surface; Compressor stroke; Pressure-flow behavior

z:row.TitlePrimary: Inertance tube optimization for kW-class pulse tubes
z:row.TitleSecondary: Advances in Cryogenic Engineering. Cryogenic Engineering Conference - CEC, 22-26 Sept. 2003
z:row.TitleTertiary: AIP Conf. Proc. (USA)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Growing interest in larger scale pulse tubes has focused attention on optimizing their thermodynamic efficiency. For Stirling-type pulse tubes, the performance is governed by the phase difference between the pressure and mass flow, a characteristic that can be conveniently adjusted through the use of inertance tubes. Unfortunately, data describing the optimized inertance geometry as a function of desired phase-shifts and acoustic power are not readily available. In this paper we present measurements of pressure, mass flow, and phase shift for inertance tubes subjected to kW-level acoustic power flows. This type of data can be used to characterize the optimal inertance geometry, length and diameter, for a desired phase shift and acoustic power. The measurements are compared to an inertance tube model based on transmission line theory
z:row.User2: inertance tube optimization; kW-class pulse tubes; thermodynamic efficiency; Stirling-type pulse tubes; phase difference; mass flow; inertance tubes; optimal inertance geometry; phase shifts; acoustic power flows; optimal length; optimal diameter; transmission line theory

z:row.TitlePrimary: Quench dynamics in silver coated YBCO tapes
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2001 Joint Cryogenic Engineering Conference and International Cryogenic Materials Conference, 16-20 July 2001
z:row.TitleTertiary: AIP Conf. Proc. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: barium compounds|critical currents|high-temperature superconductors|quenching (thermal)|silver|superconducting tapes|superconducting thin films|yttrium compounds
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The role of silver in the quench dynamics of RABiTS-processed YBCO tapes was examined. The voltage distribution along the 20 cm. long YBCO tapes with silver thickness between two and eight micrometers was measured when different transport current pulses were applied. Measurements on each sample were performed in a conduction-cooling environment at approximately 50 K. After normal regions were induced in the sample by short over-current pulses, an operating current was applied to monitor the sample recovery or quench. When scaled to the lowest critical current, a thermal runaway current was identified and found to increase with increasing silver thickness. A simple one-dimensional model of the system supported this trend. [This paper is also published in Advances in Cryogenic Engineering Volume 47, AIP Conference Proceedings Volume 613, pp. 449-456.]
z:row.User2: high temperature superconductors; quench dynamics; Ag coated YBaCuO tapes; RABiTS-processed tapes; voltage distribution; conduction-cooling environment; critical current; thermal runaway current; films; 20 cm; 50 K; YBaCuO-Ag

z:row.TitlePrimary: Quench tests of a 20-cm-long RABiTS YBCO tape
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2001 Joint Cryogenic Engineering Conference and International Cryogenic Materials Conference, 16-20 July 2001
z:row.TitleTertiary: AIP Conf. Proc. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: barium compounds|critical currents|current distribution|finite element analysis|high-temperature superconductors|quenching (thermal)|silver|superconducting tapes|thermal analysis|yttrium compounds
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Oak Ridge Nat. Lab., TN, USA
z:row.Abstract: A 20-cm-long YBCO tape fabricated by the rolling assisted Bi-axially textured substrate (RABiTS) technique was used to study the quench behavior of a second-generation high-temperature superconductor (HTS). Quench tests of the sample were performed in a conduction cooling condition with a cryocooler. The sample was subjected to a short overcurrent pulse to create normal zones, followed by a longer operating current up to the critical currents of the weaker zones of the tape. Distinctive normal zone propagation was observed for the first time on a YBCO tape. Propagation velocities of 1.4 to 8.3 mm/s were measured, which increase linearly with the current. Stability margins and a minimum propagation current were also observed. One-dimensional thermal modeling showed good agreement with the test results
z:row.User2: quench tests; RABiTS YBCO tape; rolling assisted Bi-axially textured substrate technique; high-temperature superconductor; conduction cooling condition; cryocooler; short overcurrent pulse; critical current; normal zone propagation; propagation velocity; minimum propagation current; one-dimensional thermal modeling; finite-element modeling; 20 cm; 1.4 to 8.3 mm/s; YBa2Cu3O7-Ag

z:row.TitlePrimary: Analysis of the shuttle heat loss mechanism in GM type pulse tube refrigerators
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2001 Joint Cryogenic Engineering Conference and International Cryogenic Materials Conference, 16-20 July 2001
z:row.TitleTertiary: AIP Conf. Proc. (USA)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Appl. Supercond. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In order to predict the performance of valved pulse tube refrigerators more accurately and efficiently, it is essential to understand the DC-flow and shuttle heat loss mechanisms, the main loss mechanisms in the pulse tube refrigerator. A complete analysis of shuttle heat loss has been explored using both a fluid dynamics model that includes boundary layer analyses, as well as thermodynamic considerations. The analysis also incorporates valve timing and the cold end temperature in the pulse tube. The example analysis investigates the boundary layer development and associated heat transfer through each of the various types of flow conditions realized. during the 6-step cycle of a 5-valve pulse tube refrigerator. The temperature dependent shuttle heat loss is compared with previous temperature dependent discrepancies between measured cooling power and that predicted by an ideal-gas thermodynamic model of the 5-valve cycle. The analysis provides an improved prediction of shuttle heat loss and an enhanced ability to scale the design of GM type pulse tube refrigerators
z:row.User2: shuttle heat loss mechanism; GM type pulse tube refrigerators; DC-flow; boundary layer analyses; thermodynamic considerations; valve timing; cold end temperature; boundary layer development; heat transfer; flow conditions; 6-step cycle; 5-valve pulse tube refrigerator

z:row.TitlePrimary: Visualization at cryogenic temperatures using a glass fiber bundle
z:row.Keyword: Cryogenic liquids|Glass fibers|Heat flux|Light emitting diodes|Nucleation|Nitrogen
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: A visualization method is being used to investigate features of nucleate boiling in narrow channels of liquid nitrogen. The information regarding bubble size, departure frequency, bubble spacing, and velocity will be used to develop an analytical model for critical heat flux (CHF) - especially its dependence in narrow channels on inclination angle and gap spacing. We report on the use of a glass fiber bundle combined with two different photographic and illumination techniques to study the desired bubble characteristics. The special considerations encountered with this approach at liquid nitrogen temperature are highlighted, including the use of submerged light-emitting diodes (LEDs) for illumination. © 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Glass fiber bundels

z:row.TitlePrimary: Characterizing thermal runaway in HTS current leads
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1998 Applied Superconductivity Conference, ASC-98, Sep 13-Sep 18 1998
z:row.Keyword: High temperature superconductors|Critical current density (superconductivity)|Temperature|Computer simulation|Thermodynamic properties|Electric properties|Heat conduction|Heat convection|Cooling
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Following a brief review of the many issues pertinent to HTS current lead design, we describe the performance of a pair of 1500 A HTS current leads during the transient warm-up following a loss of intercept cooling. Results describing the subsequent temperature evolution are provided both from experimental measurements and from an associated ANSYS model. The study confirms that HTS current leads must be analyzed on a systems basis - incorporating the thermal and electrical characteristics of all components - to provide useful information for the end user. A performance contrast is provided between conduction-cooled and convection-cooled modes. It is found that when heat generation in the HTS conductor exceeds convective cooling by a factor of 10 or more, that part of the current lead is thermally decoupled from the rest of the lead.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Thermal runaway; Current lead

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermodynamic analysis of active valve pulse tube refrigerators
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1997 Space Cryogenics Workshop, Aug 4-Aug 5 1997
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper presents a detailed thermodynamic analysis of the working process of an active valve pulse tube refrigerator which is introduced to enhance the performance of a single stage pulse tube refrigerator. With the aid of several simplifying assumptions, the theoretical refrigeration power and coefficient of performance of this kind of refrigerator are obtained. Simulation results illustrate that the values of two intermediate pressures play a significant role in the system performance.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: He II refridgeration system performance in the SMES proof of principle experiment
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Applied Superconductivity Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: The system performance of the He II refridgeration system used in the Ebasco team SMES proof of principle experiment is described. The system ultimately achieved a temperature of 1.85 K at a heat load of 37 W, and ran for 30 h without any problem. System elements requiring special attention, including the heat exchanger design, thermal penetrations, pumping, and plumbing, are discussed. Operating characteristics involving cooldown, lambda transition, and thermal perturbations are described. © 1997 Elsevier Science Ltd.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Test results of a 1.5 kA HTS current lead for μSMES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1996 Applied Superconductivity Conference. Part 1 (of 3), Aug 25-30 1996
z:row.Keyword: High temperature superconductors|Electric contacts|Oxide superconductors|Copper|Electric energy storage|Superconducting transition temperature|Low temperature operations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A Pair of 1.5 kA current leads incorporating a conventional (copper) upper stage, a lower BSCCO stage, and intermediate cooling from a twin-cold-finger GM cryocooler have been designed, fabricated and tested. A lower stage has been fabricated and tested using a stacked-tape sample of BSCCO-2223 material donated by American Superconductor Corporation. Test results characterize the helium boil-off rate, cryocooler power consumed, and joint resistances measured during the base line operation of the current leads at various currents. Additionally, the transient performance of the leads in response to a loss of cooling is reported. Here the temperatures and voltage drops at significant locations on the leads are reported as a function of time for the various operation conditions. Test results show that the most significant factor in determining the allowable operation time subsequent to a loss of cooling is the thermal inertia of the cold bus connecting the current leads to the cryocooler. The current leads are designed for use in a μSMES system and incorporate the necessary lead-to-lead voltage isolation within the body of the cryocooler.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: High temperature superconducting leads; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES)

z:row.TitlePrimary: Performance of a twin cold finger Gifford-McMahon cryocooler
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of 16th International Cryogenic Engineering Conference and International Cryogenic Materials Conference, 20-24 May 1996
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the Sixteenth International Cryogenic Engineering Conference/International Cryogenic Materials Conference
z:row.Keyword: high-temperature superconductors|low-temperature production|magnetic cooling|refrigeration|superconducting cables|superconducting magnets|thermal resistance
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Appl. Supercond. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A single stage Gifford McMahon cryocooler with two identical cold fingers electrically isolated from each other has been fabricated to cool a pair of 1500 A HTS current leads. 60 watts of cooling capacity are provided at 70 K on each of the cold fingers. In that the necessary voltage isolation is provided in a region where heat is transferred by the helium gas internal to the cryocooler, thermal inefficiencies associated with an electrical isolator in the cold bus conduction path are avoided. Initial performance results of the cryocooler are reported in terms of measured heat loads at various operating temperatures

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of low heat leak demountable seals for use in superfluid helium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In an experiment using superfluid helium, a successful method has been developed for sealing a G-10 to G-10 interface within the superfluid which satisfies the following requirements: (1) provision for a very good (though imperfect) thermal barrier to heat flow, (2) easy disassembly, and (3) allowance for significant roughness or mismatch between the mating surfaces. Test results using a variety of sealing methods and materials are presented; these reveal that a combination of furniture wax applied to the G-10 surfaces and a subsequent epoxy seal between the waxed surfaces provides the best means for satisfying the above requirements.

z:row.TitlePrimary: On the thermal stability length dependence of high Tc superconductors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings International Cryogenic Materials Conference/Cryogenic Engineering Conference ICMC/CEC 1995, 17-21 July 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: Advances in Cryogenic Engineering (Vol.41). Proceedings of the 1995 Cryogenic Engineering Conference
z:row.Keyword: bismuth compounds|calcium compounds|cooling|critical currents|high-temperature superconductors|multifilamentary superconductors|specific heat|strontium compounds|superconducting coils|thermal conductivity|thermal stability
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Appl. Supercond. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The margin of stability for high Tc superconductors may be characterized by the lowest thermal pulse that results in a quench. A numerical code, developed to investigate this stability margin, accounts for the temperature dependence of the thermal conductivity, electrical resistivity and heat capacity of the materials involved. The conductor is cooled solely by thermal conduction along its length, and its stability is studied as function of the length. It is found that the stability margin for a pure BSCCO 2212 conductor is independent of the length. However, the stability margin for a composite conductor obtained by adding 10% (by volume) of silver to the BSCCO is found to be strongly length dependent. A transition length is identified, for which shorter lengths exhibit a dramatically higher stability margin. This feature results when the length dependent thermal diffusion time is shorter than the time required to determine the conductor's stability. This study confirms and explains the growing awareness that if normal zones appear in high Tc coils, they will remain fairly localized
z:row.User2: thermal stability length dependence; stability margin; quench; numerical code; temperature dependence; thermal conductivity; electrical resistivity; heat capacity; pure BSCCO 2212 conductor; composite conductor; transition length; length dependent thermal diffusion time; normal zones; HTSC coils; ANSYS code; transient Fourier equation; Joule heating; current density; current leads; BiSrCaCuO-Ag

z:row.TitlePrimary: Optimization of the intercept temperature for high temperature superconducting current lead
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings International Cryogenic Materials Conference/Cryogenic Engineering Conference ICMC/CEC 1995, 17-21 July 1995

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Appl. Supercond. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Current leads containing high temperature superconducting (HTS) components have the potential to greatly reduce the heat leak to liquid helium environment. However, significant heat leak reduction can only be achieved by intercepting heat at the joint between the upper (copper) and the lower (high temperature superconducting) sections of current leads. An optimization analysis has been performed to minimize the net room temperature refrigeration power required for operating HTS current leads. The analysis shows that competing factors of cryocooler efficiencies and the influence of HTS material properties on the required helium liquefaction power determine an optimum intercept temperature in the range between 70 and 80 K
z:row.User2: HTSC current lead; intercept temperature; optimization analysis; heat leak reduction; net room temperature refrigeration power; cryocooler efficiencies; He liquefaction power; Carnot coefficient; critical current density; 70 to 80 K

z:row.TitlePrimary: Performance characteristics of the 60 kA SMES conductor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1994 Applied Superconductivity Conference. Part 1 (of 3), Oct 16-21 1994

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: We report the operating characteristics of the monolithic SMES conductor designed for operation at 60 kA, 5.1 tesla in a 1.8 K bath of subcooled helium. Details of the experimental arrangement and procedures are presented as background. At 1.85 K the conductor has been operated up to 75 kA, and with maximum field conditions of 4.25 tesla. Conductor performance is compared to the load line and design point of the Engineering Test Model (ETM). Transient stability is also demonstrated. Maximum conditions experienced by the conductor were limited by facility operation rather than by the conductor itself.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermal conductivity and contact conductance of BSCCO-2212 material
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1994 Applied Superconductivity Conference. Part 2 (of 3), Oct 16-21 1994
z:row.Keyword: High temperature superconductors|Thermal conductivity|Electric resistance measurement|Thermal load|Critical current density (superconductivity)|Interfaces (materials)|Copper
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Thermal conductivity of bulk high temperature superconducting materials is a very important property in the current lead applications because it determines the heat load of the lead at the low temperature end. The thermal conductivity of BSCCO-2212 superconducting material has been measured between 10 and 130 K. Our results compare favorably with other published results. The thermal contact conductance between a joint of BSCCO-2212 and copper has also been measured. Our results indicate that although this kind of joint provides a relatively poor thermal interface, the electrical resistance is small. This joint is still a good choice for making a easy joint which requires both thermal and electrical interfacing.

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Appl. Supercond. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The University of Wisconsin-Madison, USA, is providing technical assistance in the form of magnet design, development of HTS current leads and magnets, and integration of cryocoolers for a program directed at marketing of micro-SMES systems for power conditioning in the range of 3 MJ and 1.5 MW. The design approach incorporates BSCCO 2212 elements and an orifice pulse tube (OPT) cryocooler in the HTS current leads, and a neon-based Joule Thomson cryocooler for testing HTS magnets. This report describes efforts in progress and provides detail in the design approaches being adopted in the various micro-SMES activities

z:row.TitlePrimary: Quench detection of multiple magnet system
z:row.Keyword: Superconducting magnets|Electric equipment protection|Electric windings|Signal detection|Coupled circuits|Detector circuits|Mathematical models
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Magnet protection mandates the detection of any normal zone so that the magnet can be safely discharged. This is usually achieved by having a center voltage tap and two voltage taps at both ends of the windings. The voltage across the two sections of the winding is compared and balanced for inductance. Any voltage signal is then due only to the presence of a normal zone. This method is shown to be inadequate for mutually coupled magnet systems. As a solution to this problem a theory of voltage detection for mutually coupled magnets is presented along with a voltage detection circuit based on Gaussian elimination. The method is confirmed by experiment. Two equivalent solutions are presented which involve either additional voltage taps or the incorporation of dI/dt signals from the coupled magnets.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Multiple magnet systems; Normal zone; Voltage taps; Voltage signals; Voltage detection theory

z:row.TitlePrimary: Voltage detection and magnet protection
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1992 Applied Superconductivity Conference, Aug 23-28 1992
z:row.Keyword: Superconducting magnets|Electric equipment protection|Electric discharges|Quenching|Microprocessor chips
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Voltage detection is routinely used to identify resistive regions within superconducting magnets so that a protection circuit can trigger a safe magnet discharge. Non-resistive voltage signals, for example inductive voltages, can however produce false signals causing the magnet protection system to trip prematurely. An experimental verification is given of a quench detection method which eliminates sensitivity to inductive voltages in multiple magnet systems. In addition, a specific application of these ideas for the UW Proof of Principle Experiment demonstrates the need for incorporating a microprocessor in the quench detection system.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Magnet protection; Voltage detection; Protection circuits; Magnet discharges; Voltage signals; Quench detection

z:row.TitlePrimary: Design issues for a superfluid helium subcooler
z:row.TitleSecondary: Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Nov 8-13 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
z:row.Keyword: Cooling systems|Cryogenic liquids|Liquefied gases|Helium|Heat exchangers|Flow of fluids|Heat transfer|Superconducting magnets|Mathematical models
z:row.Publisher: Publ by ASME, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Proposed operating conditions for Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) coils will be a temperature of 1.8 K and a pressure of 0.1 MPa. The subcooled superfluid helium environment is created by a combination of a low heat leak path to communicate 0.1 MPa pressure to the liquid helium bath and a subcooler heat exchanger to lower the temperature. This report addresses the design issues critical to the components of the subcooler system including those related to the issue of operating the heat exchanger in superfluid helium, and identifies the factors which can limit the overall performance. Specifically, it discusses the details of the Joule-Thomson (JT) valve, including flow characteristics, the precooler, the Kapitza resistance across the liquid-liquid heat exchanger, and the generation of helium mass flow. Taking all the factors into account, a methodology is presented for designing to a desired capacity. The impact of the various parameters on the design of the He II system for the proposed 20 MWh Engineering Test Model (ETM) SMES coil will be studied to determine their relation to refrigerator efficiency. When constructed, the ETM will include the largest He II cooled magnet system in the world.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Superfluid helium subcooler system; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Joule Thomson valves; Kapitza resistance; Engineering test model (ETM)

z:row.TitlePrimary: Geometry dependence of steady-state heat flow in He II [superconducting magnets]
z:row.TitleSecondary: Basic Mechanisms of Helium Heat Transfer and Related Influence on Stability of Superconducting Magnets. 2nd Joint Seminar (US-Japan), 26-30 Aug. 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: Cryogenics (UK)
z:row.Keyword: heat conduction|heat transfer|superconducting magnets|superfluid helium-4|thermal conductivity
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Appl. Supercond. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Gorter-Mellink equation of steady-state heat transfer in He II is used to develop a method of calculating the peak heat flux for a magnet cooled in a bath of He II. It is shown that the equivalent thermal resistance of a series or parallel arrangement of linear cooling channels is given by Req=f(T)1/3geq where f(T) is the inverse of the heat conductivity function and geq is the equivalent geometry factor respectively defined for series or parallel channels as gs=(Σgi3)1/3 and gp=[Σ(1/gi)]-1. Here gi=Li1/3/Ai where L and A are the channel length and cross-sectional area respectively. The peak heat flux is given by q*=Z(Tb)/(A0geq) where Z(Tb) is the integrated heat conductivity function. Specific forms of the peak heat flux are developed for three different winding geometries: a simple pancake-wound magnet, a layer-wound magnet, and a multiply connected coil pack

z:row.TitlePrimary: Test results from the SMES proof of principle experiment
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1990 Applied Superconductivity Conference, Sep 24-28 1990
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A proof-of-principle experiment (POPE) has been conducted to demonstrate the stability and operation of the superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) conductor in an engineering test model (ETM) design. The experimental facility includes: a 100-kA DC power supply; a 4-T, 1-m bore, background field split solenoid; a three-turn-1-m-diameter test coil for the ETM conductor; a dewar for operation of the solenoid and test coil, at 1.8 K and 1 atm; and support systems for vacuum, helium supply and recovery, and data acquisition. The test facility exactly duplicates the electric, magnetic, and thermal conditions expected for the ETM conductor. A report is presented on measurements of conductor stability vs. transport current, applied magnetic field, and cooling from liquid helium. The measurements characterize the conductor's stability against finite-length traveling normal zones and against quenches resulting from transient normal zones. The data qualify the conductor for dependable use at 50 kA, 4 T, and 1.8 K.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Proof of Principle Experiments; Engineering Test Models

z:row.TitlePrimary: 100 kA, He II cooled conductor test facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1991 Cryogenic Engineering Conference. Part 1 (of 2), Jun 11-14 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: Advances in Cryogenic Engineering
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Plenum Publ Corp, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This report details the facility built at the University of Wisconsin-Madison for testing conductors in a subcooled helium II environment with DC currents up to 100 kA and in a field of up to 4 tesla. The cryogenic environment is provided in an annular dewar with inner and outer radii of 0.457 m and 0.725 m respectively and a height of 1.64 m. The dewar houses the split pair background magnet and test coil in a helium bath at one atmosphere and at temperatures between 4.2 K and 1.8 K. Maximum refrigeration at 1.8 K is 20 watts. Automatic systems maintain constant levels of liquid nitrogen and liquid helium in the dewar. The 100 kA DC power supply system is comprised of a high voltage AC disconnect, an 1100 KVA variable voltage transformer, the 24 pulse 100 kA, 6 V DC power supply, water cooled copper bus bars and a pair of 75 kA helium vapor cooled leads for penetration into the dewar. Additional support systems include a helium recovery system, the magnet protection system, and a 24 channel, 100 kHz data acquisition system. This facility has been used to qualify the 50 kA ETM conductor in the SMES Proof of Principle Experiment.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Helium II cooled conductor test facility; University of Washington-Madison

z:row.Abstract: A long term SMES program in the Applied Superconductivity Center (ASC) has been continuously in progress at the University of Wisconsin since the 1970-1 invention of SMES by H.A. Peterson and R.W. Boom. SMES has been the major Applied Superconductivity Center activity; superconductive materials under D.C. Larbalestier and helium cryogenics under S.W. Van Sciver are the other two major center activities. The principal interest in SMES stems from the US DNA-SDI program to build an Engineering Test Model (ETM) for utility and government use. The author give a selected Wisconsin review of SMES design highlights and of some small scale SMES studies

z:row.TitlePrimary: Two dimensional transient heat transfer in He II
z:row.TitleSecondary: Applied Superconductivity Conference - 1988, Aug 21-25 1988
z:row.Keyword: Superconducting Devices -- Low Temperature Effects|Helium--Heat Transfer|Superconducting Materials--Energy Storage
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Appl Superconductivity Cent, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A comparison is presented of transient heat flow in He II as measured experimentally and as predicted by analysis based on the Gorter-Mellink equation. The geometry is that envisioned for the He II cooling of a SMES (superconducting magnetic energy storage) system, namely, an annular layer of He II in direct contact with one layer of a solenoid and extending the full height of the coil. A normal zone over a fraction of a turn provides for two-dimensional heat flow in the annular layer of the He II. The comparison is given for both adiabatic and isothermal boundary conditions at the end of the channel. Good agreement between the analysis and the experimental data is found, verifying the usefulness of the analysis for large-scale systems. In addition, discrepancies between the analysis and data provide insight into the stability process of the He II cooled superconductor.

z:row.User2: Helium-Cooled Superconductors; Gorter-Mellink Equation; SMES (Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage); Two-Dimensional Heat Flow; Transient Heat Flow

z:row.Abstract: Studies of the stability of a single-layer superconducting solenoid are reported. Stability insensitive to the duration of the thermal disturbances boundaries are measured for variety of types of thermal disturbances. It is found that these boundaries are for disturbances less than 10 ms but are influenced by the spatial extent of those disturbances. Normal zone development in quench situations is shown to be useful in defining a relationship between the duration of the stability process and the joule heating of the conductor

z:row.Abstract: Helium II provides a unique and useful environment for cryogenic cooling of large scale superconducting devices. The heat transfer properties of this peculiar liquid afford enhanced thermal stability for composite conductors, while the low temperatures created ensure the possibility for high current densities in the superconducting material. This report discusses one large scale superconducting device, namely a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system, and demonstrates the usefulness of He II in providing the stable environment.

z:row.TitleSecondary: Advances in Cryogenic Engineering.
z:row.TitleTertiary: Advances in Cryogenic Engineering
z:row.Keyword: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Stability|SUPERCONDUCTING DEVICES - Cooling|HELIUM - Heat Transfer|ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE - Mathematical Models|ELECTRIC COILS - Windings

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This report presents measurements on the stability of a He II cooled superconductor. The conductor is helically wound in a phenolic coil support and is cooled by a channel of He II which allows for heat transfer in two dimensions. Stability is measured by recovery of the superconducting state following a transient burst of heat. The data also allows one to measure normal zone propagation velocities and temperature profiles at various times. Currents in the conductor range from 0 to 5 kA with background magnetic field ranging from 0 to 11 tesla. Descriptions of stability boundaries are given in terms of maximum energy bursts from which the conductor recovers as a function of transport current, channel size and background field. Comparisons of the data with an analysis of stability in a one-dimensional channel are shown to be useful. This experimental configuration is intended to model some aspects of a superconducting magnetic energy storage system.

z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Eleventh International Cryogenic Engineering Conference. ICEC 11, 22-25 April 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the Eleventh International Cryogenic Engineering Conference. ICEC 11
z:row.Keyword: astronomical telescopes|cryogenics|fluid dynamics|heat transfer|helium|superconducting magnets|superfluid helium-4
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: He II is being utilized in two very different low temperature technologies: superconducting magnets and space infrared telescopes. Each of these technologies places particular demands on the He II coolant. Understanding the impact of these demands on system operation is the goal of several ongoing research efforts. The authors review the current understanding of He II as it applies to these systems. Subjects to be addressed include: heat transfer and stability limits in He II cooled magnet system, He II containment under zero gravity and fluid dynamics of He II transfer in space

z:row.Abstract: Temperature-entropy (T-S) phase diagrams for helium between 1 and 7 K have been generated from available numerical codes. These diagrams show isobaric and isenthalpic slope changes at the lambda ( lambda ) point. In the He II regime, the entropy is an increasing function of pressure, which is exactly opposite to the behaviour of ordinary fluids. This effect is caused by the depression of the lambda transition with applied pressure.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Elevated-pressure mixed-coolants Joule-Thomson cryocooling
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Maytal, BZ, Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; benmay@rafael.co.il
z:row.Abstract: This paper explores the potential of mixed coolants at elevated pressures for Joule-Thomson cryocooling. A numerical model of a Joule-Thomson cryocooler is developed that is capable of simulating operation with mixtures of up to 9 components consisting of hydrocarbons, non-flammable halogenated refrigerants, and inert gases. The numerical model is integrated with a genetic optimization algorithm, which has a high capability for convergence in an environment of discontinuities, constraints and local optima. The genetic optimization algorithm is used to select the optimal mixture compositions that separately maximizes following two objective functions at each elevated pressure for 80, 90 and 95 K cryocooling: the molar specific cooling capacity (the highest attainable is 3200 J/mol) and the produced cooling capacity per thermal conductance which is a measure Of the compactness of the recuperator. The optimized cooling capacity for a non-flammable halogenated refrigerant mixture is smaller than for a hydrocarbon Mixture; however, the cooling capacity of the two types Of mixtures approach one another as pressure becomes higher. The coefficient of performance, the required heat transfer area and the effect of the number of components in the mixture is investigated as a function of the pressure. It is shown that mixtures with more components provide a higher cooling capacity but require larger recuperative heat exchangers. Optimized Mixtures for 90 K cryocooling have similar cooling capacity as those for 80 K. Optimized compactness for 80 K is about 50%, higher than can be achieved by pure nitrogen. For 90 K, no mixture provides a more compact recuperator than can be achieved using pure argon. The results are discussed in the context of potential applications for closed and open cycle cryocoolers. (C) 2005 Published by Elsevier Ltd.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Double-sided IPEM cooling using miniature heat pipes
z:row.Keyword: heat pipe|integrated power electronic module (IPEM)|power electronics|thermal management|INTEGRATED POWER|CHIP|Engineering, Manufacturing|Engineering, Electrical & Electronic|Materials Science, Multidisciplinary
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Ieee Transactions on Components and Packaging Technologies
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PISCATAWAY; 445 HOES LANE, PISCATAWAY, NJ 08855 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Martens, TJ, Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; gfnellis@engr.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: Integrated power electronic module (IPEM) planar interconnect technologies offer opportunities for improved thermal management by allowing thermal access to the upper side of the power devices. In this paper, the feasibility of using miniature heat pipes to achieve effective double-sided cooling is investigated by analyzing the complete thermal circuit associated with the power device. A nominal case was modeled using the ANSYS(tm) finite element software in a single-sided and double-sided configuration. The numerical model predicted that the double-sided configuration would result in a 13 degrees C reduction in the maximum temperature compared to the single-sided case, for the same 100 W/cm(2) power dissipation in the semiconductor die. This corresponds to a 15% decrease in the maximum temperature rise relative to ambient or a similar increase in allowable power dissipation. Twenty-eight percent of the heat was removed from the upper side of the IPENI in the double-sided case. An additional benefit associated with double-sided cooling was a significant reduction in the spatial temperature gradients along the surface of the IPENI which would translate to lower thermally induced stress and higher reliability. The sensitivity of the numerical predictions to important parameters; including the dielectric conductivity, contact conductance, and heat sink characteristics are numerically investigated. An experimental fixture was fabricated and used to measure a miniature rectangular heat pipe's performance characteristics and the solder joint resistance at its evaporator and condenser interfaces in order to validate the numerical model inputs and demonstrate the required heat pipe capacity. The tested heat pipe was limited to approximately 80 W/cm(2) heat flux in a vertical, evaporator-over-condenser orientation. This limit was not observed in a vertical, gravity-assisted orientation for applied heat flux up to 125 W/cm(2). Equivalent heat pipe resistances of approximately 0.12 and 0.08 K/W were measured in these orientations, respectively. The contact resistance of the indium solder joint was measured and found to be approximately 0.1 cm(2.)K/W.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental investigation and modeling of inertance tubes
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Fluids Engineering-Transactions of the Asme
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; THREE PARK AVE, NEW YORK, NY 10016-5990 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Cryogen Engn Lab, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Nellis, GF, Univ Wisconsin, Cryogen Engn Lab, Room 1339 Engn Res Bldg,1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; gfnellis@engr.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: Growing interest in larger scale pulse tubes has focused attention on optimizing their thermodynamic efficiency. For Stirling-type pulse tubes, the performance is governed by the phase difference between the pressure and mass flow, a characteristic that can be conveniently adjusted through the use of inertance tubes. In this paper we present a model in which the inertance tube is divided into a large number of increments; each increment is represented by a resistance, compliance, and inertance. This model can include local variations along the inertance tube and is capable of predicting pressure, mass flow rate, and the phase between these quantities at any location in the inertance tube as well as in the attached reservoir The model is verified through careful comparison with those quantities that can be easily and reliably measured; these include the pressure variations along the length of the inertance tube and the mass flow rate into the reservoir. These experimental quantities are shown to be in good agreement with the model's predictions over a wide range of operating conditions. Design charts are subsequently generated using the model and are presented for various operating conditions in order to facilitate the design of inertance tubes for pulse tube refrigerators. These design charts enable the pulse tube designer to select an inertance tube geometry that achieves a desired phase shift for a given level of acoustic power.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effectiveness-NTU relationship for a counterflow heat exchanger subjected to an external heat transfer
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Heat Transfer-Transactions of the Asme
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; THREE PARK AVE, NEW YORK, NY 10016-5990 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Nellis, GF, Univ Wisconsin, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; gfnellis@engr.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: This paper presents the analytical solution for the effectiveness of a counterflow heat exchanger subjected to a uniformly distributed, external heat flux. The solution is verified against conventional epsilon-NTU relations in the limit of zero external heat flux. This situation is of interest in applications such as cryogenic and process engineering, and the analytical solution provides a convenient methodfor treating differential elements of a heat exchanger in a numerical model.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Heat transfer coefficient measurements for mixed gas working fluids at cryogenic temperatures
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Nellis, G, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; gfnellis@engr.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: The use of mixed gas working fluids has become common in Joule-Thomson type cryocoolers for a variety of applications. However, there is very little data or theory currently available regarding the heat transfer coefficient associated with these multi-component, multi-phase mixtures at cryogenic temperatures. This paper describes an experimental test facility and procedure that has been used to make careful measurements of the horizontal, flow boiling heat transfer coefficient for several hydrocarbon mixtures that are nominally optimal for small, Joule Thomson cryocoolers in the 80 K to 120 K operating range. Data are presented over a range of temperatures from 100 K to room temperature and for several pressures and mass flow rates. The results indicate that quality and mass flux are the most important parameters governing the heat transfer coefficient among those that were varied. The experiment is verified by carrying out tests using single-phase, pure nitrogen gas and comparing the results with the Dittus-Boelter equation. The experimental uncertainty of the measurements is estimated from 1st principles; additionally, the repeatability of the experimental measurements was investigated by replicating tests at a nominal set of operating conditions and composition on separate days. The measurements presented here are intended to aid in the design of small, mixed-gas Joule-Thomson cryocoolers. (c) 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Eddy current heating in Micro-SMES bus-bars
z:row.Keyword: bus bars|eddy current heating|micro-SMES|transient film boiling|Engineering, Electrical & Electronic|Physics, Applied
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PISCATAWAY; 445 HOES LANE, PISCATAWAY, NJ 08855 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Appl Superconduct, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Pfotenhauer, JM, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Appl Superconduct, 1500 Johnson Dr,(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: Results from numerical models and theoretical analyses are presented that describe the development of eddy current heating in copper bus bars, both with and without superconducting elements, in response to the rapid decay of current in a nearby superconducting magnet such as in micro-SMES systems. The analysis differs from those available in the open literature in that the change of magnetic field is neither instantaneous, nor sinusoidal. We especially investigate eddy current heating in the regime where the field decay time is on the order of the current diffusion time constant. It is found that the self-inductance of the copper bus bar contributes significantly to the time dependent heat generation. Analytical results are compared to experimental data in the form of subsequent temperature excursions of a liquid helium cooled copper bus, in response to field ramp rates on the order of 1.5 tesla/second.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Visualization at cryogenic temperatures using a glass fiber bundle
z:row.Keyword: glass fiber bundle|light-emitting diode (LED)|critical heat flux (CHF)|liquid nitrogen|Thermodynamics|Physics, Applied
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Pfotenhauer, JM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: A visualization method is being used to investigate features of nucleate boiling in narrow channels of liquid nitrogen. The information regarding bubble size, departure frequency, bubble spacing, and velocity will be used to develop an analytical model for critical heat flux (CHF) - especially its dependence in narrow channels on inclination angle and gap spacing. We report on the use of a glass fiber bundle combined with two different photographic and illumination techniques to study the desired bubble characteristics. The special considerations encountered with this approach at liquid nitrogen temperature are highlighted., including the use of submerged light-emitting diodes (LEDs) for illumination. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Characterizing thermal runaway in HTS current leads
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Pfotenhauer, JM, Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Following a brief review of the many issues pertinent to HTS current lead design, we describe the performance of a pair of 1500 A HTS current leads during the transient warm-up following a loss of intercept cooling. Results describing the subsequent temperature evolution are provided both from experimental measurements and from an associated ANSYS model. The study confirms that HTS current leads must be analyzed on a systems basis incorporating the thermal and electrical characteristics of all components - to provide useful information for the end user. A performance contrast is provided between conduction-cooled and convection-cooled modes, It is found that when heat generation in the HTS conductor exceeds convective cooling by a factor of 10 or more, that part of the current lead is thermally decoupled from the rest of the lead.

z:row.Keyword: active valve pulse tube refrigerator|pulse tube|five valve and thermodynamic model|Thermodynamics|Physics, Applied

z:row.Abstract: This paper presents a detailed thermodynamic analysis of the working process of an active valve pulse tube refrigerator which is introduced to enhance the performance of a single stage pulse tube refrigerator. With the aid of several simplifying assumptions, the theoretical refrigeration power and coefficient of performance of this kind of refrigerator are obtained. Simulation results illustrate that the values of two intermediate pressures play a significant role in the system performance. (C) 1999 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: He II refrigeration system performance in the SMES proof of principle experiment
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Appl Superconduct, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Stanford Univ, Stanford Linear Accelerator Ctr, Palo Alto, CA 94304 USA.; Pfotenhauer, JM, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Appl Superconduct, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The system performance of the He II refridgeration system used in the Ebasco team SMES proof of principle experiment is described. The system ultimately achieved a temperature of 1.85 K at a heat load of 37 W, and ran for 30 h without any problem. System elements requiring special attention, including the heat exchanger design, thermal penetrations, pumping, and plumbing, are discussed. Operating characteristics involving cooldown, lambda transition, and thermal perturbations are described. (C) 1997 Elsevier Science Ltd.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Test results of a 1.5 kA HTS current lead for mu SMES
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Pfotenhauer, JM, UNIV WISCONSIN,1500 ENGN DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A pair of 1.5 kA current leads incorporating a conventional (copper) upper stage, a lower BSCCO stage, and intermediate cooling from a twin-cold-finger GM cryocooler have been designed, fabricated and tested, A lower stage has been fabricated and tested using a stacked-tape sample of BSCCO-2223 material donated by American Superconductor Corporation, Test results characterize the helium boil-off rate, cryocooler power consumed, and joint resistances measured during the base line operation of the current leads at various currents, Additionally, the transient performance of the leads in response to a loss of cooling is reported, Here the temperatures and voltage drops at significant locations on the leads are reported as a function of time for the various operation conditions, Test results show that the most significant factor in determining the allowable operation time subsequent to a loss of cooling is the thermal inertia of the cold bus connecting the current leads to the cryocooler, The current leads are designed for use in a mu SMES system and incorporate the necessary lead-to-lead voltage isolation within the body of the cryocooler.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of low heat leak demountable seals for use in superfluid helium
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, OXON, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Pfotenhauer, JM, UNIV WISCONSIN,CTR APPL SUPERCONDUCT,1500 ENGN DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: In an experiment using superfluid helium, a successful method has been developed for sealing a G-10 to G-10 interface within the superfluid which satisfies the following requirements: (1) provision for a very good (though imperfect) thermal barrier to heat flow, (2) easy disassembly, and (3) allowance for significant roughness or mismatch between the mating surfaces. Test results using a Variety of sealing methods and materials are presented; these reveal that a combination of furniture wax applied to the G-10 surfaces and a subsequent epoxy seal between the waxed surfaces provides the best means for satisfying the above requirements. (C) 1996 Elsevier Science Limited
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: VANSCIVER SW, 1986, HELIUM CRYOGENICS; NR: 1; TC: 1; J9: CRYOGENICS; PG: 3; GA: VM812

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermal-Conductivity and Contact Conductance of Bscco-2212 Material
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: YANG, ST, UNIV WISCONSIN,CTR APPL SUPERCONDUCT,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Thermal conductivity of bulk high temperature superconducting materials is a very important property in the current lead applications because it determines the heat load of the lead at the low temperature end. The thermal conductivity of BSCCO-2212 superconducting material has been measured between 10 and 130 K. Our results compare favorably with other published results, The thermal contact conductance between a joint of BSCCO-2212 and copper has also been measured. Our results indicate that although this kind of joint provides a relatively poor thermal interface, the electrical resistance is small. This feint is still a good choice for making a easy Joint which requires both thermal and electrical interfacing.

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,MADISON,WI.; SCHERBARTH, DW, WESTINGHOUSE SCI & TECHNOL CTR,PITTSBURGH,PA 15235.
z:row.Abstract: A joint in the superconductor and stabilizer is added to the ETM conductor in the POPE. The joint design is similar to that proposed by Westinghouse for the SMES ETM field joints. Fabrication of the joint is described. Measurements on the performance of the superconducting joint operated in subcooled He II and of the stabilizer joint at 14 K are reported. Measured superconductor joint resistance is 1.6 n Omega, which agrees with previous analytic calculations. The stabilizer joint RR matches the conductor stabilizer RR The joint met or exceeded all operational requirements throughout the experiment demonstrating its reliability and small joule heating.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Performance-Characteristics of the 60 Ka Smes Conductor
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: WESTINGHOUSE SCI & TECHNOL CTR,PITTSBURGH,PA 15235. CHICAGO BRIDGE & IRON,PLAINFIELD,IL 60544. EBASCO SERV INC,MADISON,WI 53713.; PFOTENHAUER, JM, UNIV WISCONSIN,CTR APPL SUPERCONDUCT,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: We report the operating characteristics of the monolithic SMES conductor designed for operation at 60 kA, 5.1 tesla in a 1.8 K bath of subcooled helium. Details of the experimental arrangement and procedures are presented as background. At 1.85 K the conductor has been operated up to 74 kA, and with maximum field conditions of 4.25 tesla. Conductor performance is compared to the load line and design point of the Engineering Test Model (ETM). Transient stability is also demonstrated. Maximum conditions experienced by the conductor were limited by facility operation rather than by the conductor itself.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Quench Detection of Multiple Magnet System
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: PAUL SCHERRER INST,VILLIGEN,SWITZERLAND.; HILAL, MA, UNIV WISCONSIN,CTR APPL SUPERCONDUCT,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Magnet protection mandates the detection of any normal zone so that the magnet can be safely discharged. This is usually achieved by having a center voltage tap and two voltage taps at both ends of the windings. The voltage across the two sections of the winding is compared and balanced for inductance. Any voltage signal is then due only to the presence of a normal lone. This method is shown to be inadequate for mutually coupled magnet systems. As a solution to this problem a theory of voltage detection for mutually coupled magnets is presented along with a voltage detection circuit based on Gaussian elimination. The method is confirmed by experiment. Two equivalent solutions are presented which involve either additional voltage taps or the incorporation of dI/dt signals from the coupled magnets.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: PFOTENHAUER JM, 1991, ADV CRYOGEN ENG, P155 PFOTENHAUER JM, 1992, UNPUB IEEE T MAG AUG WILSON MN, 1983, SUPERCONDUCTING MAGN, CH9; NR: 3; TC: 1; J9: IEEE TRANS APPL SUPERCONDUCT; PG: 6; GA: PU043

z:row.TitlePrimary: Geometry Dependence of Steady-State Heat-Flow in He-Ii
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, OXON, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: PFOTENHAUER, JM, UNIV WISCONSIN,CTR APPL SUPERCONDUCT,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: The Gorter - Mellink equation of steady-state heat transfer in He 11 is used to develop a method of calculating the peak heat flux for a magnet cooled in a bath of He II. It is shown that the equivalent thermal resistance of a series or parallel arrangement of linear cooling channels is given by R(eq) = f(T)1/3 g(eq) where f(T) is the inverse of the heat conductivity function and g(eq) is the equivalent geometry factor respectively defined for series or parallel channels as g(s) = (SIGMA-g(i)3)1/3 and g(p) = [SIGMA(1/gi)]-1. Here g(i) = L(i)1/3/A(i) where L and A are the channel length and cross-sectional area respectively. The peak heat flux is given by q* = Z(T(b))/(A(o)g(eq)) where Z(T(b)) is the integrated heat conductivity function. Specific forms of the peak heat flux are developed for three different winding geometries: a simple pancake-wound magnet, a layer-wound magnet, and a multiply connected coil pack.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Test-Results from the Smes Proof of Principle Experiment
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017-2394
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: WESTINGHOUSE ELECT CORP,CTR SCI & TECHNOL,PITTSBURGH,PA 15235.; PFOTENHAUER, JM, UNIV WISCONSIN,CTR APPL SUPERCONDUCT,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A Proof of Principle Experiment (POPE) has been constructed and conducted to demonstrate the stability and operation of the SMES conductor in the SMES-WISC team's Engineering Test Model (ETM) design. The experimental facility includes: a 100 KA DC power supply; a 4 tesla, 1 meter bore, background field split solenoid; a three turn-1 meter diameter test coil of the ETM conductor; a dewar for operation of the solenoid and test coil at 1.8 K and 1 atmosphere, and support systems for vacuum, helium supply and recovery, and data acquisition. The test facility exactly duplicates the electric, magnetic and thermal conditions expected for the ETM conductor. We report on measurements of conductor stability vs. transport current, applied magnetic field, and cooling from liquid helium. The measurements characterize the conductor's stability against finite length traveling normal zones, and against quenches resulting from transient normal zones. The data qualify the conductor for dependable use at 50 kA, 4 tesla and 1.8 K.
